segments.text: Today's date is the 22nd of September, 1982.
This is Terry Anderson.
This is a test.
Today is the 22nd of September, 1982.
I'm here with Dr. Fred Morrow, and we're going to talk about his background to begin with.
Tell me about your background, where you're from, your parents,
Early life?
Well, I was born in Moscow, Idaho, May 4, 1909.
When I was about two years old, we moved to Montana where my dad had a homestead.
We stayed there as homesteaders for just a couple of years and then back to the state of Washington.
where we lived in Molson, Washington, and Spokane, Washington, and back to Moscow, Idaho, where I went to school, to grade school, high school, and to the University of Idaho.
I finished University of Idaho with a degree in business administration, and
Because that was at a time when there was a national depression, we- 1934.
1934, we went and moved to Pullman, Washington, where I went to the College of Veterinary Medicine, got a degree in veterinary medicine.
Is that the main reason that you went to veterinary medicine?
That's right, the main reason.
You were thinking you wanted to be a businessman first then?
I wanted to get a job.
It was a tough time, and my primary concern was to get into a field where there was an opportunity for a job, and veterinary medicine was one of the few fields where there was jobs open.
And that was the only reason I went to college veterinary medicine.
What about your prerequisites?
Well, I had taken care of those pretty well, because initially I was going to be a dentist before I... Oh, I see.
So I had taken some pre-med along with...
business administration degree that I got at the University of Idaho.

So then I finished the vet school in 37 and took a job with the US Department of Agriculture for just a few months and then had a better opportunity with the University of Idaho to become an assistant professor there in their microbiology department.
I stayed there about a year and a half and then had an opportunity
for a fellowship at Cornell to get a PhD.
So I went to Cornell and had a fellowship and worked on my PhD until 1941 when I got pulled in the Army.
Fortunately I was in the Reserve.
So I then served in the Army and
until 1964 for 23 years.
No kidding, as a reserve officer on active duty during the war and reserve during peacetime.
And then after about 1943 or 44, I got shifted into the regular army, applied and became a regular army officer about 1933.
I mean, by 1944.
And I stayed on through 1964.
And all of my assignments in the military were in research, fortunately.
And the Army also gave me a year off to go back to, actually, to Rockefeller Foundation in New York City, where I finished my PhD.
Oh, so you hadn't completed it.
I hadn't completed it when I was at Cornell.
They put me in the service before I got it finished.
Let's stop right here for a second.
So you finished a Ph.D. then in 1948.
Yes, that's right, even though I had started it in 1940, in 1937 actually.
But because of those several years of interruption with the military, it wasn't completed until 48.
Where did they send you in the military during the Second World War?
Well, fortunately, I was initially assigned to a research lab at Front Royal, Virginia, from 41 to 42, and then to a gross eel in Canada, which was a foreign disease control station.
There was a threat of biological warfare under this hemisphere at that time, so there we studied foreign diseases, rinderpest and similar foreign diseases.

Then in 1945, to evaluate the vaccine we had developed at Grosse Ile, one other fellow and I went to Kenya in East Africa to test the vaccine in the field that we had prepared against rinderpest in Canada.
And it worked just fine, but this experience of working in Canada and East Africa got me indoctrinated into the great need
on a worldwide basis for control of foreign animal diseases of food producing livestock.
And so then when I came back from Africa in 54, I managed an assignment with the Armed Forces of Sina.
I don't want to get these dates mixed up with that.
Chief of the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology Research Committee?
Yeah, I went back to the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology in 64.
I mean, sorry, 54.
And was there in the research laboratory working on vaccines for
equine encephalomyelitis and for Jap B encephalitis and things of that sort until 1951 when I had an opportunity to go back to Africa.
I'm getting these dates wrong.
Oh, in 1951 then you were field director of a research team in Africa, that's right.
Yes, that's right.
What happened was that in 1945 I went

from Canada to Africa to test a vaccine then when I came back from there I was assigned to Walter Reed Laboratories from 45 to 51 and then I went back to Africa 51 to 54 and then was assigned to the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology where I stayed until 1961 during that time
I was, as it says there, in charge of first biology, laboratories, and then later the Department of Pathology also.
And was promoted to colonel during that time period.
And then went to Fort Knox, Kentucky, where I was in charge of the pathology department.
But all of this was in some
relationship to animal disease research.

And then upon retirement from the Army in 64, I accepted the job here as Associate Dean for Research at the College of Veterinary Medicine with the intent and statement that I wanted to establish a program here in Tropical Veterinary Medicine because of my earnest interest in this field.
Now why did you retire from the Army?
When I became a regular army officer in about 44, they gave me credit for seven years based on age so that my 30 years was up in 1964.
So I had a 30-year military retirement in 64.
That's why I left, even though I was a long ways from 60.
I hadn't reached.
I can't think just at the second how old I was at the time, but that's incidental.
Fifty-six?
Fifty-six, yeah.
Well, then I came here and served as associate dean.
Now, did you have other offers when you retired from the Army?
Yes, yeah.
There were lots of opportunities at that time.
But the main reason I came here was because of the opportunity to
work in tropical veterinary medicine as well as to serve as associate dean.
Sure.
Because of the Texas location close to the Mexican border, it was an ideal place to work on tropical diseases, you see.
It was a prime reason I came here.
Yes, there were several other opportunities at the time.
Mostly in vet schools?
Oh, yes, in vet schools at Warson State and in California and different places where there were opportunities.
But they promised you when you came here that you'd be able to work on tropical diseases.

Well, they, at least Dean Price, was encouraging that this was a possibility, and then after I had been here about a year and gotten settled down into working as associate dean for research, we developed a proposal for a program in the Institute of Tropical Veterinary Medicine, which was approved by the dean and by

President Rudder and fortunately the administrative setup was such that when President Rudder gave us the okay we were free to go out and seek funds and develop the program here which we then did in 1965 and 66 and we obtained funds initially from the Rockefeller Foundation
Now how'd you get that, by writing a grant proposal?
Yes, writing a grant proposal and through interviews with the concerned people.
And fortunately, the Rockefeller Foundation was already active with a program in Columbia in South America, so it wasn't difficult for us to integrate into that program with
research that could be conducted there that could not be conducted in Texas.
So that's why we have this Colombian connection now.
That's right.
Because I was wondering why you went with Colombia and not with Mexico or someplace closer.
Well, there had been some contacts and some interviews and some work done with Mexico, but it was because of the Rockefeller Foundation collaboration with a Colombian project
at SEAT, their Center for International Tropical Agriculture, that we first became involved in their laboratory in Bogota, Colombia.
And we had our own lab then in Bogota for about two years.
And then our activities were moved to SEAT in Colombia to
down near Cali, Columbia.
And there for then, for the following period of about 10 years, we had an active program in Cali with six or eight faculty people from here in Columbia, as well as the staff here at Texas A&M.
And those things are
our parents from the papers that I have given you, the details on that.
Okay.
And then- So this is in 1966 when you proposed for development, and when did you get the grant?
Well, right away.
We got it in 66.
We started the program in 66.
Okay, you also had a research proposal to the United States AID.
Yes, and it was funded- In 67, yeah.

And then in about 68 or 69, I'm not sure exactly which now, we got a separate second funding from USAID for the so-called 211D program, which permitted us to work in Guyana, South America, as well as in Columbia.
So we had some research going on in Guyana as well as in
Columbia, South America for some time.
Now, when you originally made these proposals, did you have specific diseases or specific areas that you wanted to work?
Yes, we did.
What were those ideas and how did that change?
We were primarily concerned with hemoprotozoal diseases, Babesia, Anaplasma, because those are

major handicaps to livestock production, cattle production particularly, in Latin America, also because the so-called Texas fever that once was a major problem here was still prevalent in Latin American countries.
That disease had once cost the United States about $40 million a year.
And we knew that to eradicate it in
Latin American countries would increase their productivity considerably.

It would also provide a major opportunity for Canadian livestock producers to be able to ship, I'm sorry, I mean Texas livestock producers to be able to ship Texas cattle to Latin America to improve their breeding stock and greatly enhance the market for Texas cattle abroad.

And we later, after we had done quite a bit of research in developing means of immunizing against Babesia, we did send some herds from Texas to Latin America, which got along just fine and stayed healthy down there and improved local livestock breed.
Great.
And what countries in Latin America?
Well, we sent some to some
Central American countries and also some herds to Columbia.
How'd you pick these cattle?
Where'd you get these cattle from?
Well, they were Texas breeders that had high quality cattle that wanted to sell them in Latin America for a good price.
And they were able to do that, you see, some breeding cows and bulls and so on.
And because of the success of those efforts, we received offers for and grant funds from
African countries that also would like very much to improve their breeds of cattle in Africa if they could be immunized against these same diseases which are prevalent over there.
In fact, we had a ten million dollar offer from Nigeria.
They were going to provide the money and they have enough oil money there now that they could afford to do that.
Did they?
No, they didn't because
By that time, which was in the late 70s or mid-70s, there had been administrative changes at the university higher than the College of Veterinary Medicine.
OK, well, we'll get to those.
But let's get back then to the early 1960s.
In other words, it seems to me that, and correct me if I'm wrong, but it seems to me that there were
not only medical reasons and research reasons to go and set up the institute, but also economic reasons?
Is that true?
Yes, you bet.
That was a major consideration because there's no question but what the world in general is in desperate need of more food resources.
And the cattle, for example, food producing livestock in many countries are greatly handicapped by disease.
So to eliminate disease problems would increase their productivity and make them more self-sufficient countries.
And even in the early, late 60s and 70s, there was at that time many countries of the world where people were starving.
And matter of fact, there's some 15,000 people starving to death every year at that time.
and about one eighth of the world's population going to be hungry every night.
So there was a desperate need to increase world food production.

And that was the basis primarily of our incentive, plus the fact that to do something about improving the health environment for livestock abroad, they could improve their livestock and make them more productive.
and provide a tremendous market for the United States to export better breeding stock, which we have.
For example, one American dairy cow will produce as much milk as ten African cows.
No kidding.
And one American steer will produce as much beef as about six of theirs.
Those animals in Africa for the most part are terribly stunted for lack of
disease control, lack of adequate nutrition, lack of water, and breeding.
Because for centuries, they have been geared to survival, not to productivity.
While our animals have been fed well and well cared for and properly bred and increased for productivity.
So there's a tremendous need and opportunity to improve livestock abroad, and that
Those two things are the key factors that stimulated our efforts in this direction.
And because of world population, now the need for increased food production is greater today than it was 15, 20 years ago.
Now, during the 1960s, when your institute is beginning to get steam, there is a tremendous shift in American history and in society toward
are with people who are much more interested in the world.
LBJ at this time comes out and starts talking about overpopulation of the earth.
We start sending birth control pills and stuff like that to India.
It's been foreign aid the first time we've ever done that.
Did any of this have any impact whatsoever on the institute?
Well, yes.
All of those things which have a bearing on

population control are important factors in relation to world need for food, but there has persisted since the early 60s a growing need for food on a worldwide basis because of increases in population.
It's somewhat of a tragedy that the scientific developments which have controlled disease and increased longevity of man have also had
such an effect on population that they have increased population to the point where food supplies cannot increase as fast as population has.
See, in 1600, it took a thousand years for population to double.
Today, world population is doubling every 30 years.
And in Salvador, for example, every 21 years.
In Kenya, every 28 years.

with population increasing so much more rapidly than food supplies possibly can there's bound to be desperate starvation or war will wipe them out as an alternative okay let's talk about some of the specific research some of the other specific research programs that you had at the institute well we were primarily concerned with these
hemoprotozole diseases.
Now this was done from the standpoint of trying to develop vaccines but also a medicinal means of controlling those diseases.
We also received some small grants from drug manufacturers in the United States that wanted us to evaluate drugs that could be used to help with the control of these same diseases.
No kidding.
So we had
Funds from three sources really, from Rockefeller, from Aid, and from some commercial sources.
Did you have any breakthroughs?
What did you consider your successes?
Well, the major successes were in providing a means of immunizing against Babesia.
And also methods for the treatment of anaplasmosis.
Both of these were definitely improved and were far better because of our experience with them than they had been before.
To my knowledge, we were the first people that were ever able to export immunized cattle from Texas to Latin America and have them survive down there.
And also, large studies conducted in Columbia, we were able to immunize young animals

and then let them run in the field where they were fully exposed and they resisted the disease and remained healthy, you see, and were far more productive with very minimal losses compared to native cattle.
Could you give me some statistics?
I mean, how larger did the cattle get?
How much longer did they live in general?
How much more productive were they?
Did you do any surveys as far as that was concerned?
Yes, and I'm sure that
that there is ample evidence within the papers that are published papers which are in this collection here that will give you that information.
And there was definite progress because well for one thing you couldn't import cattle before and have them survive.
Eighty percent of them would die.
No kidding.
Eighty percent?
That's right.
They just can't stand those diseases down there where there's
tremendous tick populations that carry the disease.
And if they come in as susceptible adults, they just don't last long.
Almost all of them die.
But when they're immunized as young animals, then they get along all right.
Are the animals still there?
Yes.
Yeah, they're still doing fine.
And have you heard anything over the last year or so about that?
Well, you see, once immunity is established, then exposure to the disease by infected ticks only stimulates their increased immunity.
So if they get through that early period of when they're no longer susceptible, they become increasingly resistant.
So they'll live as long as any other cattle.
Now, did you hear, I mean, were there...
projects that you thought you could make some headway but turned out that they were not successful?
Well, all of these things you go through growing stages of constant improvement until you get it the best you can, you know.
So I'm sure that in our early trials down there we weren't as successful as we were in later ones because one has to learn how to do these things and do them right.
But were there things that you thought that you failed at?
No, I don't really think so because the method of immunization that we used in Latin America and here is called pre-immunization.
It's a matter of developing a strain of the organism which is mild from the standpoint of producing disease but still produces a good solid immunity.
In other words, you give them a little bug and then let the natural forces take over.
That's right.

was to develop a strain of organisms that could be used in young, fully susceptible cattle that would not produce disease in terms of any clinical signs, but would develop a strong immunity that was lifelong lasting.
And it was certainly maintained even better when they were later exposed to the fully virulent field strains of the disease.

so it turned out very well now sure there were trial and errors in the beginning in developing this strain to the point where it was safe to use and where it would produce good immunity and sometimes we use some of these medicinal agents along with the early inoculation to get them through that first stage and keep them healthy while they developed immunity but later we didn't even have to do that
So it's a growing trial and error process.
Is the vital time the first six months or a year?
Well the first six or eight weeks is a critical time until they get through the possibility of developing clinical illness and become immune.
Now are there differences between treating the animals or giving the vaccination to animals who are down in the country versus giving them to American cattle and then shipping them down?
The main difference is that indigenous cattle produce calves which have some level of immunity because they get it from the colostrum of their mother.
So they're a little better to start with than the fully susceptible cattle here.
But in either case, they can be immunized properly.
Now let's talk a little bit about the relationships that you had with the state and federal government.
You must have had some contact.
The Institute must have had contact with the state government and the federal government.
Well, that's right.
We did.
We met frequently with the USAID in Washington because they were funding our project.
We met with the USDA numerous times because
They were sincerely interested in our activities.
As a matter of fact, some of our former staff are now working on a USDA project in the state of Washington to carry on the same work that we were doing here.
I was going to ask about that.
Dr. Cutler, who was a principal research man for us in this program, is now heading
a laboratory in Washington State with branches in Idaho, and just doing the same work and continuing on with it.
Were there other colleges that had, at the time when you set up the institute, were there other colleges in the country?
Was there any other vet school that you knew of that was doing tropical diseases?
This was the first program in tropical veterinary medicine, to my knowledge, in the United States.
No kidding.
Now there were some individual professors
in a couple of places that had some interest, but this was the first program with a sizable staff.
And that's another question I have.
What was the size of the staff?
How did it grow?
How did it change?
Well, it grew from one or two of us to where we had, well, the details are in some of this write-up that I have given you, but we typically had

about six staff members from Texas A&M who were professors and assistant professors, and then probably 15 or 20 technicians, and usually half a dozen graduate students, many of whom were foreign graduate students from Latin America and Europe and even Africa, people that were sent here to learn more about this program so they could help when they got home.
So between the Columbian program, the Guyana program, and Texas, we probably had ordinarily eight or ten staff members and about twenty technicians plus graduate students.
Okay, let's get back to the relationships that you had with the federal government.
Did, in what, I mean were there
Of course, this program could have implications for the State Department and for foreign policy.
Did you have any relations with the State Department?
Was there any time that they came out and they said, well, we don't want you to- If you would like to look at the CV there with the consultant group and the committees, there was lots of interest.
See, I was involved with the US Livestock Sanitary Association on their foreign animal disease committee on their infectious diseases of horses.
And during that same time period, I was on the research committee of the American Veterinary Medical Association and chairman of that committee for several years.
And also, many of these foreign trips were sponsored
by agencies other than USAID or Rockefeller.
There were several of them sponsored by National Academy of Science that were interested in these things.
And for example...
